form.steps:
1. Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart, engaging your core, and maintaining a neutral spine. 
2. Take a big step forward with one leg. 
3. Lower your body until your front knee is bent at a 90-degree angle and your back knee is close to the floor. 
4. Push off with your front foot to return to the starting position.

form.Torso: Keep your torso upright and your core engaged throughout the exercise.
form.Front Knee: Ensure your front knee tracks over your toes and doesn't collapse inward.
form.Back Knee: Lower your body until your back knee is close to the floor, but don't let it touch.
form.Weight Distribution: Distribute your weight evenly between your front and back foot.

commonMistakes.Leaning Forward: Avoid leaning forward excessively, which can strain your lower back. Keep your torso upright.
commonMistakes.Limited Range of Motion: Performing shallow lunges reduces muscle activation. Aim for a full range of motion, lowering your body until your front thigh is parallel to the ground.
commonMistakes.Knee Valgus: Prevent your front knee from collapsing inward, which can stress the knee joint. Keep your knee aligned with your toes.

comments.Progression: You can progress this exercise by adding weight, such as dumbbells or a barbell, or by performing variations like walking lunges or reverse lunges.
comments.Balance and Coordination: Bodyweight lunges are excellent for improving balance and coordination.
comments.Unilateral Exercise: As a unilateral exercise (working one leg at a time), lunges can help address strength imbalances between legs.

alternativesAndVariations.Barbell Lunge: Performing the lunge with a barbell across your upper back increases the resistance and builds greater lower body strength.
alternativesAndVariations.Dumbbell Lunge: Holding dumbbells in each hand during the lunge provides a balance challenge and allows for variations like a bicep curl at the top of the movement.
alternativesAndVariations.Reverse Lunge: Instead of stepping forward, step backward into the lunge. This variation can be easier on the knees for some individuals.
alternativesAndVariations.Walking Lunge: Adding a forward movement to the lunge, alternating legs with each step, creates a dynamic exercise that challenges stability and coordination.
alternativesAndVariations.Bulgarian Split Squat: Elevating your back foot on a bench during a lunge increases the stretch in the hip flexor and the activation of the quads and glutes in the front leg.

body-weight-lunge.tempo: 2010 (2 seconds lowering, 0 seconds pause at the bottom, 1 second lifting, 0 seconds pause at the top)
